title.narrative: OUTPUT 1.1 MATERNAL NEONATAL HEALTH

description.narrative: Output 1.1 By 2025, the Government and stakeholders at national and subnational level will have increased capacity to expand and sustainably provide, while families and communities will have an increased capacity to demand, an integrated package of quality services for pregnant women, including pregnant adolescents, and new-borns in development and humanitarian situations, and urban settings., which contributes to Fast-Track The End Of Hiv/Aids, Immunization Services As Part Of Primary Health Care, Strengthening Primary Health Care And High-Impact Health Interventions, Strengthening Primary Health Care And High-Impact Health Interventions (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building, Systems Strengthening To Leave No One Behind. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: 1.By 2025, new-borns, children and adolescent boys and girls, especially the most disadvantaged and those living in humanitarian situations, have increased access to and use of quality integrated health, nutrition, HIV and early stimulation services and benefit from a more nurturing, protective and clean environment

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: Output 1.1 By 2025, the Government and stakeholders at national and subnational level will have increased capacity to expand andsustainably provide, while families and communities will have an increased capacity to demand, an integrated package of qualityservices for pregnant women, including pregnant adolescents, and new-borns in development and humanitarian situations, and urbansettings.

description.narrative: Through partnerships, UNICEF supported development and dissemination of policy documents, guidelines, evidence generation, capacity development, and monitoring of continuity of essential health and HIV services. This was instrumental in strengthening support for MNH and PMTCT. UNICEF prioritized district health systems strengthening with a focus on district planning and prioritization, data-driven performance reviews, data quality assurance, quality improvement;with MPDSR as a main entry point, peer-led community-facility linkages with service delivery. Systems support for on-site mentorship, surge staff support, essential equipment and supplies, improvement of physical health environment, were prioritized. These contributed to improved access and quality of services. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:06/01/2022
